snippet: A shift in the front line of the battle against illegal crossings has intensified debate over an immigration overhaul; some say a Texas influx shows the need to prioritize border security.
abstract: Surge in migrant traffic across Southwest border into Texas has made state's Rio Grande Valley the front line in battle against illegal crossings from Mexico, shifting emphasis away from Arizona for first time in more than decade; change has intensified bitter debate under way in Senate over whether border is secure enough to move ahead with legislation granting legal status to millions of illegal immigrants already in country.

byline.original: By ERIC LIPTON and JULIA PRESTON
byline.contributor: Laura Tillman contributed reporting from McAllen, Tex.

lead_paragraph: A shift in the front line of the battle against illegal crossings has intensified debate over an immigration overhaul; some say a Texas influx shows the need to prioritize border security.

headline.main: As U.S. Plugs Border in Arizona, Crossings Shift to South Texas
headline.print_headline: As U.S. Plugs Border in Arizona, Crossings Shift to South Texas
